data.title: Lou Reed 1942-2013: A rebel who helped shape 50 years of rock
data.meta_description: The singer who walked on the wild side with Velvet Underground has died aged 71
data.text:
When Reed started out in the late 1960s with The Velvet Underground, the band was so ahead of its time their music was derided. It was thanks to the album artwork by Andy Warhol that the experimental group got any recognition.

They may not have had mass appeal, but Reed and Welshman John Cale inspired many of their cult following to form bands.

David Bowie once described Reed as his all-time hero. Others who credit his influence include The Jesus and Mary Chain, REM and U2.

His passing was announced with a cryptic note on his Twitter and Facebook pages, possibly posted by himself, saying simply: "The Door."

Iggy Pop said Reed's death was "devastating news".

The Who said: "R.I.P. Lou Reed. Walk on the peaceful side."

And author Irvine Welsh tweeted: "I really doubt that there would have been Trainspotting without Lou Reed."

Bisexual Reed, born in Brooklyn, always played down his musical talents .

He once joked: "One chord is fine. Two chords are pushing it. Three chords and you're into jazz."

Reed leaves a widow, performance artist Laurie Anderson, 66, whom he married five years ago.
